titlestmt.titleproper: Register to the Papers of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya
titlestmt.author:
Compiled by Adrienne Nesnow
Consultants: Lys Symonette and Kim Kowalke

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:10

did.unittitle: Register to the Papers of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya

langmaterial.language: Materials chiefly in English and German.

did.abstract: Music, correspondence and other papers, photographs, and additional materials by and about the German-American composer Kurt Weill (1900-1950) and the German-American actress and singer Lotte Lenya (1898-1981)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment. Some of the materials may be stored at the Library's off-campus shelving facility, so researchers should allow at least two business days to have the appropriate boxes paged.Permission to view certain correspondence must first be obtained from the Kurt Weill Foundation for Music, Inc., 7 East 20th Street, 3rd Floor, New York, NY 10003.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Papers of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya were established in the Music Library of Yale University by Lenya in 1981.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Papers of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 30, The Papers of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 16 series as follows: I. Music by Weill. II. Arrangements for Lenya. III. Music by Others. IV. Correspondence. V. Programs. VI. Photographs. VII. Documents. VIII. Writings by Weill and Lenya. IX. Scripts and Lyrics for Works by Others. X. Interviews. XI. Biographical Items. XII. Financial Items. XIII. Loose Clippings. XIV. Clippings from Anna Krebs's Scrapbooks. XV. Miscellaneous Items. XVI. Kurt Weill Conference Items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Papers of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya contain manuscript scores and sketches of Weill's music, including American stage works as Down in the Valley, Lady in the Dark, One Touch of Venus, Street Scene, Lost in the Stars, Love Life, Firebrand of Florence, and Johnny Johnson. Music for stage works written in Germany includes the holograph scores for Happy End and Mahagonny-Songspiel. Photocopies of holograph scores for other works from his German period, including Die Dreigroschenoper and Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny, have been provided from the archives of Universal Edition, Vienna, which holds the original manuscripts. Other musical scores and sketches in the collection include the Cello Sonata, Symphony No. 1, String Quartet Op. 8, Quodlibet, Sinfonia Sacra, Frauentanz, Concerto for Violin and Wind Instruments, Das Berliner Requiem, Vom Tod im Wald, Symphony No. 2, You and Me, Railroads on Parade, Walt Whitman Songs, Where Do We Go From Here, A Flag Is Born, Weill's arrangement of the Israeli national anthem Hatikvah, and various arrangements of Weill's music for performances by Lenya after his death. Correspondence, programs, clippings, photographs, and personal documents belonging to Weill and Lenya comprise the remainder of the collection. The correspondence spans the entire careers of Weill and Lenya, and includes letters to and from their friends, families, and collaborators such as Georg Kaiser, Bertolt Brecht, Maxwell Anderson, Ira Gershwin, Ogden Nash, S.J. Perelman, and Langston Hughes. Photographs of Weill, Lenya, family, and friends, of musical productions by Weill, and of stage and film appearances by Lenya are included among the papers. The 20,000 clippings in the collection date from their early years in Berlin.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Kurt Weill was born in Dessau, Germany on March 2, 1900. His father was a cantor and composer of Jewish sacred music, so Weill received musical training from an early age. He later studied with Humperdinck at the Berlin Musikhochschule for a year, but his most important composition teacher would prove to be Ferruccio Busoni, with whom he studied for several years in Berlin.

In the early phase of his career, Weill supported himself by working as a radio journalist and music teacher. (Maurice Abravanel and Claudio Arrau were numbered among his pupils.) Several of Weill's works were published and performed in this period, but he gained wider acclaim with his opera Der Protagonist(1926), with a libretto by Georg Kaiser. Weill and Kaiser also worked together on Der Zar lässt sich photographieren and Der Silbersee. Weill's most celebrated collaborator, however, was Bertolt Brecht, who wrote the texts for works such as Mahagonny Songspiel, Das Berliner Requiem, Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny, and Die sieben Todsünden. Their greatest success was Die Dreigroschenoper (1928), which caused an international sensation and made Weill financially secure. Although he specialized in music for the theater, Weill also composed instrumental works in the 1920s and '30s, including symphonies, string quartets, and a violin concerto.

As a left-leaning modernist intellectual of Jewish birth, Weill was an obvious target for Nazi hostility, and he fled to Paris shortly after Hitler's rise to power in 1933. In 1935 he moved to the United States, where he remained for the rest of his life. In America Weill composed numerous works for Broadway, ranging from the popular Knickerbocker Holiday, Lady in the Dark, and One Touch of Venus to the tragic Street Scene; he collaborated with a remarkable series of playwrights and lyricists including Ira Gershwin, Moss Hart, Langston Hughes, S.J. Perelman, and Ogden Nash. He also wrote four film scores. Several songs from Weill's dramatic works became popular hits, most notably "Die Moritat von Mackie Messer" (from Die Dreigroschenoper, and known in English as "Mack the Knife") and "September Song" (from Knickerbocker Holiday). Weill died in New York in 1950.

Karoline Wilhelmine Blamauer, who used the name Lotte Lenya, was born in Vienna in 1898. She began her career as a dancer in the Zurich ballet in 1914. In 1920 she moved to Berlin, where two years later, encouraged by Georg Kaiser, she became involved in the spoken theater. Kaiser also introduced Lenya to Weill, whom she married in 1926. She sang in the 1927 performance of Mahagonny-Songspiel at the Baden-Baden festival, and in 1928 she appeared as Jenny in Die Dreigroschenoper in Berlin, a role that won her international acclaim. Lenya appeared in three more of Weill's works during his lifetime: Die Sieben Todsünden, The Eternal Road, and The Firebrand of Florence. Weill and Lenya divorced in 1933 and remarried in 1937.

After Weill's death, Lenya devoted much of her time and energy to promoting and performing his music. The Threepenny Opera (Marc Blitzstein's English adaptation of Die Dreigroschenoper) was a resounding success on Broadway, and in 1956 Lenya won a Tony Award for her performance. Her activities were not limited to her husband's works, however, and she appeared in a number of other plays and films: Tennessee Williams' The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone, Brecht on Brecht, the James Bond thriller From Russia with Love, the Broadway production of Cabaret, The Appointment, and Semi-Tough. She died in 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Weill/Lenya Papers include holograph, manuscript, and published music by Weill, as well as Weill's arrangements of music by other composers. Copies of many holograph and manuscript scores from Universal Edition in Vienna, as well as a copy of Weill's arrangement of Hatikvah from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, and sketches for Gustav III from O. W. Neighbour, are included.

Twelve microfilms of several individual works had been made prior to the processing of the papers. The remainder of the music by Weill has been microfilmed also (15 reels). Items which were not filmed include duplicate copies of parts, photographic copies of items, and librettos and published music unless they contain manuscript markings. Reel and frame numbers for the items contained in the 15 reels are indicated in the register after the collation, for example, R.1, Fr.1-163. These reels are in the boxes indicated below: box 110: reels 1-6; box 111: reels 7-12; box 112: reels 13-15.

The boxes are housed in the Assistant Librarian's office in the Music Library. A positive copyflo copy has been made from a microfilm of the full score of Der Zar lässt sich photographieren from Universal Edition. Master negatives of all the microfilms are housed in the Beinecke Library under the music deposit number 83.
The provenance of a copy of any item from another source is noted in the description under the entry.

Music by Weill is divided into nine subseries by genre. Letters are assigned to each of David Drew's genre divisions in The New Grove with the exception of the final subseries, "I," which contains unidentified sketches. The works are arranged alphabetically by title within each subseries. Uniform titles are used to bring together all of the manifestations of a work with various titles. Cross-references refer one from other forms of titles to the uniform titles. Cross-references have also been made between related works and for forms of a work such as sketches, which are found with another work.
The titles for each work are arranged alphabetically without regard to punctuation:
Dreigroschenoper
Dreigroschenoper. Arie der Lucy
Dreigroschenoper; arr. der Lucy
Dreigroschenoper. Libretto. English
Dreigroschenoper. Moritat vom Mackie Messer. Text
Dreigroschenoper. Selections
Dreigroschenoper. Tango-Ballade. Vocal score
Dreigroschenoper. Vocal score

The date or dates for a work appear in the first entry only, unless the item includes a date. The folders are numbered consecutively throughout the entire series. Oversize items are housed in boxes which are at the end of the entire collection, in order to save shelf space.

[4] Arietta (10 sheets). [5] You're far too near me (25 sheets). [6] Alessandro the Wise (25 sheets). [7] Finaletto [note to copyist laid in] (17 sheets). [8] Duchess entrance music (5 sheets). [9] Sing me not a ballad (20 sheets). Stick 'em up (1 sheet). [10] When the duchess is away (21 sheets). [11] Life and love and laughter (13 sheets). [12] Cosy nook song (9 sheets). [13] Finale 1st Act Part I [Finale Act 1 Part I (of 3)] (23 sheets). [13] Tarantella [Finale Act I - Part II] ([69] sheets). - Act II: II. Act Opening (Reprise Far too near me) (4 sheets). [15] Naked little boy [note that theme is p. 9A and 9B] (15 [ie. 16] sheets). [14] Letter (Weill-Gershwin) (8 sheets). [Just in case (Part I of 2) [score is missing]. [16] Just in case (Part II) (Weill-Gershwin) [Part II (of 2)] (19 sheets). [17] Rhyme for Angela (23 sheets). [18] Procession (10 sheets). [19] Trial scene part I [of 2] [includes Trial Dance pp.A-G] (sheets 1-38, A-G). [19] Trial scene part II [of 2] ["How wonderfully fortunate" is crossed out] (8 sheets). [19e] Love is my enemy [2 versions of p. 14] (15 sheets). Nos. 25 Reprise "Naked boy" [Reprise - The little naked boy] ["Melodrama" is crossed out] (5 sheets). [20] Come to Paris (Weill-Gershwin) (18 sheets). [21b] From gigue [Gigue] (sheets 19-20, 1-18). [21a] Sarabande (sheets a-c, 1-7). [Unlocated material (Paris scene? Ceremonials?)] ([18] sheets).

odd.head: General

odd.head: General
odd.p: Contents: Aufforderung an (die) den amerikanischen Flieger, den Ozean zu überfliegen. Vorstellung des Fliegers (Charles Lindbergh). Aufbruch des Fliegers (Charles Lindbergh) in New York zu seinem Flug nach Europa. Die Stadt New York befragt die Schiffe. Lindbergh kämpft mit Nebel. Lindbergh kämpft mit Schneesturm. Lindbergh kämpft mit Schlaf. Während des ganzen Fluges sprachen die amerikanischen Zeitungen unaufhörlich von Lindberghs Glück (Die Gedanken Amerikas). Die Gedanken des Glücklichen. Schreiben die französichen Zeitungen: So fliegt er, über sich die Stürme. Lindbergh spricht mit seinem Motor. Endlich, unweit Irlands sichtet Lindbergh Fischer. Auf dem Flugplatz Le Bourget bei Paris in der Nacht den 21. Mai 1927 abends ein den amerikanischen Flieger. Ankunft des Fliegers Charles Lindbergh auf dem Flugplatz Le Bourget bei Paris. Bericht über das Unerreichbare.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Contents: Aufforderung an die amerikanischen Flieger, den Ozean zu überfliegen ([2] sheets), Aufbruch der Fliegers Charles Lindbergh in New York zu seinem Flug nach Europa ([3] sheets). Die Stadt New York befragt die Schiffe ([4] sheets). Nr. 5. Fast während seines ganzen Fluges ([9] sheets). Hatte der Flieger mit Nebel zu kämpfen. In den Nacht kam ein Schneesturm ([7] sheets). Schlaf ([4] sheets). Während des ganzen Fluges sprachen alle amerikanischen Zeitungen unaufhörlich von Lindberghs Glück ([3] sheets, [3] sheets of sketches). No. 9. Die Gedanken des Glücklichen ([4] sheets). Schreiben die französichen Zeitungen: so fliegt er, über sich die Stürme, um sich das Meer, und unter sich den Schlaffen Nungessers ([4] sheets). Lindberghs Gespräche mit seinem Motor ([2] sheets). Endlich, unweit Schottlands, sichtet Lindbergh Fischer ([4] sheets). Auf dem Flugplatz Le Bourget bei Paris erwartet in der Nacht der 21 Mai 1927 Abends 10 Uhr ein Riesenmenge der amerikanischen Flieger ([7] sheets). Ankunft des Fliegers Charles Lindbergh auf dem Flugplatz Le Bourget bei Paris ([3] sheets). Bericht über das Unerreichbare ([7] sheets).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Musical works arranged for Lenya include manuscript and published music by Weill and others. The series is divided into two subseries: A. Arrangements of Weill's works; and B. Arrangements of music by others. Arrangements of Weill's works are grouped by the same genre divisions used in Series I. The titles within each genre are arranged alphabetically. The items in the second subseries are arranged alphabetically by composer. Information concerning uniform titles, cross-references, alphabetization, housing, and box and folder numbering appears in the series description for Series I: MUSIC BY WEILL.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is divided into eleven subseries which are arranged alphabetically by sender or recipient except for the last five subseries, which are arranged chronologically. Cross-references are provided for variant forms of names, from individuals to corporate bodies or vice versa, and for enclosures. Enclosures are counted among the number of items. Restricted items which are housed either at the Music Library or at the Kurt Weill Foundation are indicated as such in the register. Permission to see these items must be obtained from the Kurt Weill Foundation.
